text:
The Unhappy VOYAGE.

Giving an Account of the Royal Anne Galley, Captain Willis Commander, which was split to Pieces on the Stag Rocks on the Lizard the 15th of November, 1721, having on board the Lord Bellhaven, who was going as Governor to Barbados, with several other Persons of Distinction, the whole Number on board being 210, out of which there were only three saved; whose Names are George Hain, William Goffey, and Thomas Laurence, a Boy.

To the Tune of, Women's Work is never done, &c.

O! the sad and dismal Story,
Issuing from the Lizard Rocks;
The Royal Anne in all her Glory,
There receiv'd a fatal Shock:
The Winds and Waves did both conspire,
For to ruin all therein:
Oh! Bellhaven, brave Bellhaven!
Most unhappy hath thou been.

Governor unto Barbados,
He was failing bold and brave,
Little dreaming it was his Fortune,
For to have a watry Grave.
With many more noble Persons,
Which were put in Place of Trust,
But oh! their Sands were left expiring,
Their Time was come and die they must.

Above two hundred souls were perish'd,
In an Infant all were lost,
And when the Waves were driven,
On the Stag Rocks they were cast:
Oh! the dismal Cries and Screaming,
'Twould have pierc'd a Heart of Stone,
When the Galley split to Pieces,
For to hear their piteous Moan.

Of those that were on board the Vessel,
Only three were left on the Shore,
Who on a Wreck by the Winds were carried,
Thro' the Waves and Billows roar:
Then brake the Lord for his great Mercy,
Yea they shall have been deliver'd,
Adore and make me, Great Godhead,
Willingly your Maker serve.

Captain Willis was Commander,
At this most unhappy Time,
Would be Attorney General,
With many more noble in their Prime,
Where going over for to settle,
At Barbados we do hear,
But by the Ocean they were follow'd,
While they did their Course steer.

What a Scene did fill Horror,
There was nothing but our O'er,
Bodies floating on the Ocean,
By the Waves were drove on Shore,
And the Country People running,
Saw them who would get the most,
Stripping all without Diffraction,
'Tis the Custom of the Coast.

One Gentleman was drove on Shore,
Born whom they found a thousand Pound,
Whose Name's suppos'd to be Goffey,
By Writing in his Pocket found.
Likewise they say the Lord Bellhaven,
Having on a Diamond Ring,
Had Shown himself in the Ringing Ocean,
Did to Shore his Body bring.

Oh! the Grief and sad Diffraction,
Which this Accident hath brought,
On the Wives and near Relations,
Of the Persons that are lost.
Some for their Wives, Sons, Fathers,
Brothers, Kindred do lament,
With aking Hearts, and weeping Eyes,
To think how from them they are rent.

But now observe the dismal Story,
Given by the three that's sav'd,
George Hain, William Goffey,
And Thomas Laurence, a Boy 'tis said,
As to Barbados we were failing,
Lord Bellhaven, he did say,
Come noble Boys and jovial Sailors,
Happy may our Voyage be.

But drawing near unto the Lizard,
There the Storm began to rise,
Nothing then but Defolation,
Did appear before our Eyes,
Such a dreadful Scene of Sorrow,
That none could bear,
Oh! Bellhaven! brave Bellhaven!
Most unhappy hath thou been.

Captain Willis cry'd brave Sailors,
Do your best, or die we must,
Lord have Mercy, now receive us,
In the Promise of the Lord,
Save us in the Time of Danger,
For Death before our Eyes appears,
And when they found all Hope were over,
In Tears they all fell down to Prayer.

The Agony of the fatal Rocks,
The Royal Galley split in twain,
Two hundred Souls aloud were crying,
Lord save us from the watry Main,
To each fall a tear a shirting,
As the Lord tell Moses said,
The Galley in the Deep a flinting,
While dying Groans did pierce the Sky.

Let the Noble Lord Bellhaven,
Climbing to the Top of the high,
With many more at Birth and Breeding,
Who likewise in the Waves did die,
At length the Galley split in Pieces,
Death put an End to all their Woe,
We are poor cast upon a Wreck,
With Waves was toss'd too and fro.

At length upon the Shore was driven,
Where the People took us in,
We praise the Lord for his great Mercy,
Since he preserved our Lives,
And fell in the fatal Hour,
When the Waves did us surround,
And many Souls did perish,
And before our Eyes were drown'd.

Oh! the dreadful Grief and Sorrow,
That their Wives and Children bore,
Wives and Mothers, Sons and Handmaids,
The Children for their Father dear,
Let each tender Heart implore them,
And pity the Sorrow they are in,
And think upon the Lord Bellhaven,
How unhappy he has been.

A noble Lady in the City,
Hearing of her Husband's Death,
'Twould have mov'd a Heart of Pity,
To hear the Words she did expect,
Her Son Bellhaven is dead,
Is a watry Wave thy Tomb,
I'll search the Deep to find my Dear,
O cruel Death come feize me soon.

Thus the raves in fad Diffraction,
In her Bed she lay pale and benumbed,
One Night and Day my Sweet,
He is in the Ocean drown'd:
Thus many a mournful Widow,
And Babies Fatherless so many,
Consider the Lord's Mercies,
Which the Sailors thro' do wade.

Many more that Night did perish,
In the Storm as we do hear,
As in the Downs the Fleet was riding,
Some Lord Bellhaven did share,
Lord keep us from such Difficulties,
Deliver us from hidden Death,
And give us Grace that we may serve,
The mighty God while we have Breath.
